Rousseau |birth_date = {{birth date|1750|03|26}} |birth_place = [[Riom]], [[Puy-de-Dôme]], [[Auvergne (region)|Auvergne]] region, [[France]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1795|06|17|1750|03|26}} |death_place = [[Paris]], France |nationality = [[France|French]] |occupation = politician and mathematician |prizes = |religion = none ([[atheist]]) |known = Developed the [[French Republican Calendar]] }} '''Gilbert Romme''' (26 March 1750 – 17 June 1795) was a [[France|French]] [[politician]] and [[mathematician]] who developed the [[French Revolutionary Calendar|French Republican Calendar]]. ==Biography== '''Charles-Gilbert Romme''' was born in [[Riom]], [[Puy-de-Dôme]], in the [[Auvergne (province)|Auvergne]] region of France, where he received an education in medicine and mathematics. After spending five years in [[Paris]], he went to [[Russia]] to become the tutor of [[Pavel Alexandrovich Stroganov|Paul Stroganoff]]. He returned to Paris in 1788 and entered political life. He was a member of the Masonic lodge, [[Les Neuf Sœurs]]. Elected in 10 September 1791 to the [[Legislative Assembly (France)|Legislative Assembly]], Romme aligned himself with the [[Girondist]]s, but after his election to the [[National Convention]] on 6 September 1792, he sided with the [[The Mountain|Montagnards]]. He voted in favour of the death sentence for [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]]. Later, in the events leading up to the [[Reign of Terror]], he was arrested by Girondist supporters and was imprisoned in [[Caen]] for two months. During his tenure in National Convention, Romme served in the ''Comité de l’instruction Publique'' ([[Committee of Public Education]]), where he presented his Republican calendar on 17 September 1793. Aware of their military importance, he also was an early supporter of [[Semaphore line|semaphore telegraphs]]. He served as president of the Convention from 21 November to 6 December 1793. Because he was on an assignment to organise gun production for the navy, he had no hand in the coup of [[9 Thermidor]] ''an II'' (27 July 1794), which resulted in the fall of the [[Robespierre]] (and ultimately led to the return of the Girondists). When rioting [[sans-culottes]], demanding bread and the [[French Constitution of 1793|Jacobin constitution]], violently occupied the Convention on [[Prairial]] ''an III'' (20 May 1795), Romme supported their demands. This insurrection was quickly put down however, and he and other Montagnards were arrested. While waiting for their trial, the defendants agreed to commit suicide in case of a death sentence. On Prairial 29 (17 June 1795), Paris, France, Romme and five others were sentenced to the [[guillotine]]. With a knife hidden by [[Jean-Marie Claude Alexandre Goujon|Jean-Marie Goujon]], he stabbed himself repeatedly while on the staircase leading from the courtroom, and died — his last words are reported to have been "I die for the republic". In ''Romme le Montagnard'' (1833), Marc de Vissac described Romme as a small, awkward and clumsy man with an ill complexion, and a dull orator, but also as possessing a pleasant and instructive style of conversation. == Sources == * [http://www.archontology.org/nations/france/france_state1/romme.php A biography of Romme] * [http://www.classicreader.com/read.php/sid.2/bookid.106/sec.156/ The French Revolution (Thomas Carlyle)] * [http://labit501.upct.es/ips/libros/TEHODN/ch-2-2.2.html#3-2.2.4 The Semaphore Telegraph] * {{fr icon}} [http://www.royet.org/nea1789-1794/notes/acteurs/romme.htm Gilbert Romme] * {{fr icon}} [http://www.geneaguide.org/russie/franco_russe_r.htm Genea Guide] {{French Revolution navbox}} {{Authority control|VIAF=12418169}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Romme, Gilbert | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 26 March 1750 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Riom]], [[Puy-de-Dôme]], [[Auvergne (region)|Auvergne]] region, [[France]] | DATE OF DEATH = 17 June 1795 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Paris]], France }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Romme, Gilbert}} [[Category:1750 births]] [[Category:1795 deaths]] [[Category:People from Riom]] [[Category:French politicians]] [[Category:People of the French Revolution]] [[Category:French atheists]] [[Category:Occitan people]] [[Category:Les Neuf Sœurs]]
